description: 6th Armd began landing on Utah Beach 18 July and closed in bivouac near Les Mesnil 24 July.
First troops were committed 27 July.  6th Armd passed through 79th inf Div south of Lessay 29 July, forcing the Sienne River at Pont de la Roche in the first battle; then captured Brehal 20 July.
All resistance in Granville are overcome 31 July.
Passed through 4th Armd Div at Avranches and Pontaubault and advanced on Pontorson, seizing a bridge there and another at Antrain Sur Couesnon after a stiff battle at Bree 1 Aug.
At Lanvallay 2 Aug 6th Armd struck and forced in the Dinan outpost with one column which then by-passed the city.  One column captured Broons and another Mauron after sharp fights 3 Aug.
Considerable resistance was overcome at Huelgoat and Le Cloitre 5 Aug after Carhaix was by-passed.
Other engagements enroute to Brest were fought at Chateauneuf, east of Pleyber Christ, and at Lesneven 6 Aug.

In the Brest area met resistance at Plouvien and Bourg Blanc and strong defenses on the line Gousenou-Gulpavas 7 Aug.  The German 266th Div struck the 6th Armd in the rear night of 8 Aug and was completely destroyed 9 Aug in and southwest of Plouvien.  Area to north and west cleared and Brest outpost line developed 10-12 Aug.  One combat command left to contain Brest 13-18 Aug.
Div less CCA relieved 4th Armd and contained Lorient 14 Aug – 15 Sept. Aggressive patrolling and artillery action.

CCB moved to Lorris.  Div actively contained Brest and Lorient and patrolled 460 miles from Crozon Peninsula to Auxerre.  Contact made at Autun with patrols of Seventh Army advancing from Southern France.
CCB relieved 4th Armd, cleared Luneville and surrounding areas and established outposts 19-20 Sept.
CCB cleared stubborn enemy from Armaccount-Leyr area 22-23 Sept.
Div counterattacked and restored Cops MLR in vicinity of Foret de Gremecey 1 Oct.
Div cleared west bank of Seille River against extremely determined enemy resistance 8-9 Oct.  Casualties were hight on both sides.
Div shifted north and crossed Seille River, drove through 80th Inf Div bridgehead, and began bitter battle to the Saar  9-10 Nov.
In a rapid thrust two bridges were secured intact over the Nied River and held against determined counterattacks 11 Nov.
13 strongly defended towns seized in 2 days as the enemy contested every foot of muddy ground 12-13 Nov.
Landroff held against a vicious enemy counterattack of reinforced regiment 14-15 Nov.
A 3-pronged attack up the slippery Cote de Suisse conquered 6 towns and high ground overlooking Faulquemont 16 Nov.
Enemy anti-tank ditches, road blocks, AT guns, SP guns and small arms delayed advance but CCB crushed eight defended towns 19-22 Nov.
CCA swung north and CCB punched east to break through enemy-held Maginot Line 24-26 Nov.
West bank of Maderbach River secured in decidedly unfavorable weather as enemy retreated east toward Siegfried Line 27-28 Nov.

6th Armd crossed Maderback River and seized La Mont de Cadenbronn in 3-day attack over difficult terrain and against vigorous resistance 4-6 Dec. 13 defended towns were captured and Div stood on German border
Patrol of CCA were first American troops in Saareguemines 6 Dec.
6th Armd suddenly ordered to Metz enroute to Belgium to help halt German Ardennes offensive 24 Dec.
Entering “Battle of the Bulge,” 6th Armd initially held a defensive sector on south flank of Ettelbruck 26 Dec.
6th Armd shifted to Bastogne and joined in extremely bitter fight.  CCA attacked to make first offensive thrust into enemy salient 31 Dec.
Intense fighting raged in deep snow and near zero weather northeast of Bastogne as enemy attempted to surround and capture town 1-3 Jan.
Three separate counterattacks repulsed when enemy drove savagely into front-line positions. 4 Jan.
German attacks grew weaker because of severe l losses inflicted on enemy personnel and vehicles 6-8 Jan.
Turning point in the “Battle of the Bulge” 9-10 Jan. 6th Armd struck northeast from Bastogne over snowclad hills littered with enemy dead and destroyed vehicles 9-12 Jan.
Mageret retaken 13 Jan.
Longvilly taken and held against a vicious counterattack as enemy attempted to withdraw to Siegfried Line with all possible equipment 16-17 Jan.
Trois Vierges captured 23 Jan after minefields were cleared and blown bridges were by-passed or rebuilt.
6th Armd reached “Sky Drive” overlooking Our River and Siegfried Line in Germany 25 Jan.
6th Armd relieved 26th and 90th Inf Divs along “Skyline Drive” on a  6-mile front 27 Jan.
After crossing Our River at flood stage, the Div established a bridgehead facing the Siegfried Line 6-7 Feb.
17th AB Div relieved by 6th Armd which took over additional front totaling 20,000 yards 10-12 Feb.
6th Armd penetrated Siegfried Line, capturing 32 town, 253 pillboxes and over 1,000 prisoners 20-24 Feb.
Crossing was forced over Prum River at night against heavy and determined enemy resistance 27 Feb.
Attacking across the Nims River, 6th Armd advanced eastward to capture Schonecken 2-3 Mar
6th Armd relieved by 90th Inf  Div and passed to SHAEF Reserve near Arzfeld.  After 221 consecutive days in action the entire Div was out of contact 4 Mar.
6th Armd was loaned to Seventh Army and returned to its old battle grounds in Lorraine 9-11.  Mar. Prepared to pass through Siegfried Line for the second time.
Div moved to advanced assembly at Oermingen 18 Mar.
6th Armd passed through the 3rd, 45th, and 63rd Divs to penetrate the Siegfried Line near Zweibrucken 20 Mar.

After racing 60 miles in 18 hours to reach the Rhine River, 6th Armd made contact with 4th Armd at Worms.  Rhein-Durkheim – only town on Rhine to be taken by XV Corps – was captured by 6th Armd 21 Mar.
Crossed Rhine at Oppenheim and captured Morfelden, Wixhausen, Russelsheim and Raunheim 25 Mar.

6th Armd converged on Frankfurt, capturing Sachsenhausen, Offenbach, Niederrad, Sprendlingen, and Neu-Isenburg.  Partially destroyed bridge was captured against bitter opposition 26 Mar, and shallow bridgehead into city of Frankfurt established and turned over to 5th Div.
Div crossed Main River at Dornigheim, drove north across Nidder River at Nieder Dorfelden and Vilbel to Friedberg 28 Mar.
Spearheaded with 4 columns abreast astride the Reichsautobahn through Friedberg, capturing Bad Nauheim and reaching Romrod 29 Mar.
After racing 50 miles Div drove through Alsfeld, Homberg and Harte to cross Eder River.  8,000 prisoners were aken 30 Mar.
6th Armd attacked toward Kassel against stiff resistance.  Crossed Fulda River at Malsfeld 31 Mar.

6th Armd advanced with Combat Commands abreast and crossed Wehre River at Reichensachsen.  Resistance was spotty but stubborn.  Spangenberg, Adelhausen, Hess Lichtenau, Waldkappel as well as many other towns were captured 2 Apr.
Div captured Eschwege, crossed the Werra River at Gross Burschia, and advancd 16 miles east 3 Apr.
6th Armd surrounded and captured Mulhausen in perfectly executed double envelopment 4-5 Aprl
Besides holding 38-mile front in First and Third Army zones, the Div captured Langensalza 6 Apr.  Advance east halted on order.
German counterattack was repulsed a Struth and area east of Bad Soden was cleared.  Enemy force of about 1500 troops reinforced with tanks and self-propelled guns was completely destroyed 7-9 Apr.

6th Armd passed through 76th DIv in four columns and advanced 60 miles to cross the Saale River.  An Allied OPW camp at Bad Sulza and the concentration camp at Buchenwald, 3 miles NW of Weimar, were freed 11 Apr.
Div advanced 28 miles to secure crossing over Weisse_Elster River at Pegau and Rosendorf.  Heavy AA defenses of Seitz-Leipzig line were overcome 12-13 Apr.
After crossing Mulde River at Rochlitz and Zachopa River at Mittweida the 6th Armd stopped at Corps limiting line 15 Apr, pending arrival of Russian Army.
